item.title: Grow A Garden: How to Farm Money Fast
item.description:
Grow A Garden is a cute and cozy Roblox game where you can build your dream garden, check out your friends' farms, and chill around the neighborhood. To decorate your farm and enjoy the game to the fullest, you’ll need plenty of Sheckles (the in-game money) since most crops and tools come with a high price tag.

With that said, earning coins in this gardening sim isn’t always easy, and it can leave some players confused. So, if you’re looking to earn Sheckles fast and become super-rich in Grow A Garden, this guide breaks it down with handy tips to help out.

How to Farm Money Fast in Grow A Garden

Here are all the ways you can make money in the game:

Grow and Sell Crops

One of the easiest ways to earn money fast in Grow A Garden is by growing crops and selling them to Steven, the local merchant. It’s the main method for farming Sheckles, though it might feel a bit slow or tricky when you’re just getting started. But with a few good tips, it gets way smoother.

  • Start with permanent crops —the ones that keep giving fruits or veggies and don’t take ages to grow. Strawberries, Blueberries, and Tomatoes are great picks. They’re not super pricey, but they bring in steady cash, especially when you get mutations (more on that later). You can also mix in a few one-time crops like Orange Tulips, Daffodils, and Coconuts to bring in lots of coins for affording better seeds later on.
  • Since your farm has limited space, plant wisely —arrange seeds so they don’t take up too much room, allowing you to fit more and earn more.
  • Now, about mutations—these boost your crop value like crazy. Some show up randomly, others happen when it rains or during a thunderstorm, and some can be triggered using gear like sprinklers. For example, a one-kg Chocolate Carrot can go for 40,000 Sheckles. The best mutations to aim for are Shocked and Rainbow —they can increase your crop value up to 50 times.

Other Methods to Make Quick Money

While selling crops is the primary way to earn money in Grow A Garden , there are a few other methods that help, too. First off, players can collect free coins from the main shop (look at the bottom left). These daily rewards don’t give much, but they’re great for beginners trying to buy cheap crops and get started.

You can also grab Sheckles Bundles from the Limited-Time Shop. They will cost real money and aren’t recommended, but they’re a solid option if you’re cool with spending. Here's what’s available in the game:

  • 100 Coins – 49 Robux
  • 250 Coins – 99 Robux
  • 1,000 Coins – 325 Robux
  • 5,000 Coins – 895 Robux

Your comment has not been saved

Roblox
227
8.8 /10

September 1, 2006

item.title: 7 Best Games That Were Made For Consoles That Flopped, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Segagaga on Dreamcast was a satirical RPG about saving Sega, featuring genre chaos and quirky mechanics.
  • Pocket Kingdom on N-Gage was a trailblazing mobile MMO with deep gameplay mechanics and global interactions.
  • Immercenary on 3DO was a cyberpunk FPS with unique combat mechanics and eerie visuals ahead of its time.

When a console flops, it usually takes a lot of good games down with it. Sometimes, it’s due to poor marketing. Sometimes, it’s the hardware being way ahead—or behind—its time. And sometimes, the stars just don’t align. But for the few diamonds that manage to sparkle on a sinking ship, it’s like finding a secret level in a game no one told you existed. These are the games that didn’t just rise above the mess—they made the mess worth digging through.

Here’s a look at several incredible games that were buried by the failure of the consoles they launched on, ranked from “surprisingly great” to “this game deserved a monument.”

7 Segagaga – Sega Dreamcast

The Game Where You Literally Try to Save Sega From Bankruptcy

Your comment has not been saved

Segagaga
RPG
Systems
Released
March 29, 2001

Developer(s)
HitMaker
Publisher(s)
Sega
Platform(s)
Sega Dreamcast
Powered by

On paper, Segagaga sounds like a fever dream. In practice, it somehow manages to be even weirder. Released exclusively in Japan in 2001 near the end of the Dreamcast’s life cycle, this satirical RPG put players in charge of a fictionalized version of Sega, tasked with saving the company from being destroyed by a rival conglomerate named DOGMA. It’s less a game and more a self-roast—an unfiltered look at Sega’s own missteps, complete with parodies of their franchises, digs at the console wars, and a healthy dose of existential corporate dread.

What’s wild is how committed it is to the bit. The opening hours play like a traditional RPG, but soon devolve into genre chaos: management sim mechanics, shoot-em-up sequences, and even PowerPoint-style meetings. One battle has players win over disgruntled employees by hurling inspirational phrases instead of attacks. Another has Sonic locked away in a cage for being “outdated.” No one was safe, and Sega was clearly in on the joke.

The Dreamcast’s commercial failure meant Segagaga never got the spotlight it deserved, but in retrospect, it’s almost poetic. A self-aware love letter to a company on the edge, only accessible to the most loyal fans who stuck around until the bitter end.

6 Pocket Kingdom: Own the World – N-Gage

The World’s First Mobile MMO Was on the N-Gage, and Somehow It Slapped

Pocket Kingdom: Own the World

Released
November 24, 2004
Platform(s)
N-Gage
Powered by

Most people remember the N-Gage for being the Taco Phone that tried (and failed) to be both a gaming handheld and a cellphone. But tucked into its library was a game that did something no one saw coming in 2004: Pocket Kingdom: Own the World became the first mobile MMO to offer persistent online play. It had cross-player interactions, economy-building, asynchronous battles, and live market trading—all on a phone that you had to hold sideways to talk on.

Players managed a crew of looters and sent them out on automated raids, with battles and encounters playing out in real time while they were away. The game blended idle mechanics with resource management and surprisingly deep equipment customization. Guild rivalries played out via global leaderboards, and rare loot drops became digital status symbols before that was even a thing.

What makes it more impressive is how it functioned on Symbian OS with a D-pad. It had no right to be this fun, but it was—and if it had launched on literally any other platform, Pocket Kingdom would be considered a trailblazer rather than a relic.

5 Immercenary – 3DO

A Cyberpunk FPS That Tried to Predict VRMMOs... In 1995

  • Platform(s) : 3DO
  • Released : 1995
  • Developer(s) : Five Miles Out
  • Genre(s) : RPG, FPS

There’s a strange melancholy to Immercenary , and not just because of its digital-dystopia setting. Released for the 3DO in 1995, it drops players into a virtual world called PERFECT, where people have uploaded their consciousness to escape a dying planet. The goal is to climb the ranks and defeat the system’s ruler, but everything—from the floating enemies to the grainy full-motion video—feels off in a way that’s hard to shake.

Technically a first-person shooter, Immercenary blends RPG mechanics with resource-based combat, where every action drains the player’s energy pool. Positioning, target prioritization, and careful planning matter way more than reflexes. And while its visuals haven’t aged gracefully, the weird, dreamlike art direction somehow makes it feel timeless in its own, unsettling way.

The 3DO’s price tag and chaotic launch schedule doomed it commercially, but Immercenary still managed to make a mark on anyone who touched it. It was Tron meets System Shock , with just a pinch of Lawnmower Man weirdness thrown in for good measure.

4 Gates Of Zendocon – Atari Lynx

The Killer App of a Console That Was Dead on Arrival

  • Platform(s) : Atari Lynx
  • Released : 1989
  • Developer(s) : Epyx
  • Genre(s) : Shooter

The Atari Lynx might’ve been the first handheld with a color screen, but it also had the battery life of a sneeze and a marketing budget that couldn’t keep up with Game Boy’s juggernaut status. Still, Gates of Zendocon made a compelling case for why the Lynx deserved better. This 1989 side-scrolling shooter featured 51 interconnected levels, alien allies that helped in combat, and multiple endings based on player choices, on a handheld, before most consoles even dared to try it.

The levels weren’t just palette swaps either. Some had gravity shifts, others were maze-like gauntlets filled with traps. Each world ended with a warp gate, and players could choose different routes, creating a quasi-branching narrative that made replays genuinely rewarding. The eerie soundtrack, surprisingly smooth framerate, and organic enemy designs made it feel more advanced than a lot of early Genesis shooters.

If Gates of Zendocon had landed on Game Boy, it would’ve been a classic. Instead, it became a footnote in a console war that Atari never really showed up for.

3 Shenmue – Sega Dreamcast

The Game That Changed Open Worlds Forever, But Only on a Console That Couldn’t Stay Afloat

Your comment has not been saved

Shenmue
Action-Adventure
Systems
9.0 /10
Released
December 29, 1999
ESRB
t

Powered by

Shenmue wasn’t just ahead of its time—it was from a completely different timeline. Released in 1999, this was Sega’s moonshot, their magnum opus. With a production budget of around $47 million, it became one of the most expensive games ever made, and it shows. Every drawer could be opened, every NPC had a name and a schedule, and weather patterns shifted in real time.

Set in Yokosuka in 1986, players stepped into the shoes of Ryo Hazuki, a teenage martial artist investigating his father’s murder. But the genius of Shenmue wasn’t in the story—it was in the world. Time moved forward whether Ryo acted or not, meaning players had to plan around store hours, bus schedules, and their own patience. They could feed stray cats, practice their moves in parking lots, and waste hours playing full versions of Hang-On and Space Harrier at the local arcade.

The Dreamcast’s collapse meant Shenmue never became the franchise Sega envisioned, but it laid the groundwork for open-world design in ways that GTA 3 would popularize years later. For those who played it, though, the wait for that elusive forklift job to start was never a chore—it was part of the magic.

2 Muramasa Rebirth – PS Vita

This Gorgeous Action-RPG Was the PS Vita’s Crown Jewel

Your comment has not been saved

Muramasa Rebirth
Action RPG
Fighting
Action-Adventure
Systems
Released
April 9, 2009

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

ESRB
t
Developer(s)
Vanillaware
Platform(s)
PS Vita, Nintendo Wii U, Wii
Powered by

Muramasa Rebirth feels like a moving painting where every brushstroke bleeds combat finesse. An enhanced port of the Wii’s Muramasa: The Demon Blade , it landed on the PlayStation Vita in 2013 with crisper visuals, refined controls, and all-new DLC storylines that added four playable characters. But what really made it shine was how effortlessly it used the Vita’s gorgeous OLED screen. Every sword swing left trails of light, and every blossom in the background felt alive.

Players controlled either Momohime or Kisuke, two warriors tied to cursed blades, exploring a mythological version of Edo-period Japan. The combat was fast, fluid, and addictive, encouraging players to juggle swords mid-air while dodging like a sidescrolling Dante. The game’s crafting system, which involved forging demonic blades with unique special moves, gave the hack-and-slash combat real depth.

The Vita itself never got the audience it deserved, which meant Muramasa Rebirth got lost in the shuffle. But among those who played it, it’s remembered as one of the handheld’s definitive experiences—and a reminder that even doomed hardware can produce something timeless.

1 Panzer Dragoon Saga – Sega Saturn

A JRPG Masterpiece Trapped on a Console That Almost No One Owned

Your comment has not been saved

Panzer Dragoon Saga
RPG
Systems
Released
January 29, 1998
Developer(s)
Team Andromeda
Publisher(s)
Sega

Platform(s)
Sega Saturn
Powered by

There are rare games, and then there’s Panzer Dragoon Saga . Released in 1998 during the final gasps of the Sega Saturn, it’s not just considered one of the greatest RPGs of its generation—it’s also one of the rarest. Only around 20,000 copies were produced for North America, and Sega disbanded Team Andromeda shortly after launch. Yet somehow, this four-disc epic still managed to become legendary.

Set in the same post-apocalyptic world as the earlier Panzer Dragoon rail shooters, the game ditched linear levels in favor of full 3D exploration, blending real-time and turn-based combat into a system that still feels innovative decades later. Players rode a morphing dragon through desolate wastelands, uncovering secrets of a lost civilization while managing movement and attack angles mid-battle. The story was haunting, full of cryptic lore and quiet tragedy, and backed by a soundtrack that could’ve carried an Oscar-winning film.

The Saturn’s botched Western launch, weak third-party support, and general mismanagement meant almost no one had a chance to play Panzer Dragoon Saga when it mattered. Today, it exists mostly in memory, emulation, and collector circles—but for those who experienced it, no other RPG has quite matched its tone, ambition, or atmosphere.

item.title: Skate Has Bad News for Fans, But Confirms Early Access Launch Window
item.description:
Summary

  • EA and Full Circle's Skate reboot enters early access in 2025, but the game lacks an offline mode.
  • The Skate developers note that the game's setting, San Vansterdam, will evolve and change over time in an always online sandbox.
  • More playtest invites will be sent out in June 2025 ahead of the early access launch.

EA confirmed that the new Skate reboot will enter early access in 2025, but the game will not have an offline mode like previous entries in the series. The new Skate game will be free-to-play with microtransactions, and members of the Skate Insiders program can experience some of what San Vansterdam has to offer for gamers around the world later this year.

The Skate reboot was revealed in 2020, nearly a decade after players experienced Skate 3 , the latest entry in the series, for the first time in 2010. Excitement for the game continued to build leading up to the first Skate playtests in 2022. In recent years, EA expanded its playtests to more users and platforms, including PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X|S. Fans have known what to expect from Skate for a while now, although the wait continues for its early access release.

Skate will enter early access later this year without an offline mode, according to EA and Full Circle's first "The Grind" blog post. The developers explain that Skate and the in-game city are designed to be a "living, breathing massively multiplayer skateboarding sandbox" that's always online and evolving. Skate players will notice changes to the city over time with live events and other in-game activities. To fulfill this vision, Skate must require a live network connection just like in the playtest.

Skate Will Not Have an Offline Mode When the Early Access Version Launches in 2025

EA notes that Skate's early access launch will be "Day One" of the live sandbox experience, and new features and improvements will be implemented in the weeks and months following the launch. Skate's controversial microtransactions from the playtest will be present in the early access version and the full release. The developers note that money spent on San Van Bucks, the in-game paid currency, will support the ongoing development of Skate while offering a system that feels fair to all players.

Extensive testing is being conducted in the PC and PlayStation playtests of Skate in order to gauge player feedback about the microtransactions and "catch any issues or pain points." It's worth noting that the San Van Bucks spent during the playtest will be transferred to the early access version of Skate upon launch. For example, if a player spends $20 in San Van Bucks, they will receive the same amount in return when Skate launches in early access this year.

Although the lack of an offline mode may be disheartening for longtime Skate fans, they will have an opportunity to get into the playtest to try some of the game's features. EA confirmed that a large wave of playtest invites for Skate will be sent out in June. More details about the game's early access version will be revealed in the coming months as well.

item.title: Oblivion Remastered: 7 Best Items To Get Early
item.description:
Summary

  • Obtain essential items such as Repair Hammers early on to sustain gear for lengthy adventures.
  • Aquire Lockpicks to access useful items in locked chests found throughout the game.
  • Gather the Cairn Bolete, a versatile mushroom for both health restoration and Alchemy.

When it's time to save Tamriel from the forces of Oblivion, even the most determined heroes have to start somewhere. As with any great RPG, The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion Remastered features a wide variety of items that players can pick up from the very start of the game , but most of them are only good for resale value.

It's important to look out for valuable or useful gear, weapons, and other miscellaneous items when the game starts, so that players can get a head start on rescuing Martin Septim and closing the gates of Oblivion. These early-game items in Oblivion Remastered aren't valuable or rare; they're just useful and easy to find.

7 Repair Hammer

Essential For Long-Term Adventuring

  • Where To Find: Locked chests, looted from bodies, purchased from shops

The player's low-quality gear at the beginning of the game wears out fast, and facing an enemy with broken weapons and armor isn't ideal. The player might even need repairs before finishing the tutorial and escaping from the city, and then there's the journey to Kvatch to find Brother Martin that takes place immediately afterward .

Instead of changing gear or stopping at a strange location for repairs, adventurers can save some time and money if there's a Repair Hammer in their inventory. It's best to have a few of them on hand, because they get used up fast, with one hammer lasting for only two or three repair jobs.

6 Lockpicks

Every Character Needs Them

  • Where To Find: Looted from Bandits and chests

Even in the original Oblivion , the lockpick minigame had its detractors, with many noting the vast improvement seen in The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim . In Oblivion Remastered , however, players still have the old version of lockpicking, and that means a lot of Lockpicks will break, even on Easy locks, until the character raises their Security skill.

Several locked chests that the player can find throughout the game contain all kinds of useful items, especially at the beginning of the campaign. Unlike some other RPGs, there's no option to break a locked chest to reveal at least some of the contents, so if players want to get into these chests, they have to collect as many Lockpicks as possible as soon as they can.

5 Akaviri Katana

Easily Obtained Early In The Game

  • Where To Find: Drops in the sewer and is available at the Cloud Ruler Temple via the Blades membership.

Those who follow the game's main quest line to Cloud Ruler Temple will have access to some better gear if they join up with the Blades. Once the player delivers Martin to the Temple safely, they'll be able to join the elite soldiers tasked with protecting the Imperial family, and that means access to better weapons, training, and repairs.

Other than handy amenities like beds and storage, there are some nice weapons here, and one of them is the Akaviri Katana . It's not a rare or valuable weapon, and players will find more of them in various places, but it's a durable, fast blade to have early on in the game.

4 Weak Healing Potion

Picked Up, Purchased, or Crafted

  • Where To Find: Looted from bodies or crafted with a Mortar & Pestle

Players will find a few of these before they find the ingredients and build up the skill to make Potions themselves, and it's best to assign them to a fast key as soon as they are picked up.

During the tutorial, the assassins in red robes will drop a few different low-level potions, and some of them are useless, but there are a few health options in the mix. Weak Healing Potions are about as good as players can expect in the first few hours of Oblivion Remastered, but they're still worth having on hand.

3 Mortar And Pestle

Required For Crafting Potions And Poisons

  • Where To Find: Found in chests or purchased from merchants.

The sooner players can start leveling Alchemy, the better, and there's a Mortar & Pestle in the Tutorial that's easy to pick up. After reaching the natural caves portion of the underground sewers, kill the goblin sitting at a table and take their Mortal & Pestle from the nearby table. A small tutorial opens up the first time players pick one up, no matter where they find it.

Unlike in Skyrim , which requires a whole table for Alchemy, all players need to craft potions and poisons in Oblivion a Mortar & Pestle in their inventory. When they click on it, another window opens, which includes a list of ingredients on the left and the mixing station on the right.

2 Dremora Mace

A Powerful Weapon For A Starting Character

  • Where To Find: Drops from Dremora on the plane of Oblivion.

It's nothing special in the way of enchantments or buffs, but the Dremora Mace is one of the deadliest and nicest-looking weapons available in the early stages of the game. It's found in the Plane of Oblivion, easily accessible via the fiery Gate just outside Kvatch.

As the player fights their way through this hellscape, seeking a way to close the gate, they will meet the servants of Mehrunes Dagon, demon-like beings known as Dremora. They carry some nice weapons, and the Dremora Mace, with 12 damage and a relatively fast attack speed, is one of the better ones.

1 Cairn Bolete

An Important Base Ingredient

  • Where To Find: A plentiful fungus that likes caves, shorelines, and shady undergrowth.

The Cairn Bolete is a useful mushroom that can be consumed raw or used as an Alchemy ingredient. Its main function is to restore Health, but players can find many more uses for it if they keep experimenting with other ingredients, which is also easy because they can find plenty of it in the wild or buy it from taverns and inns.

Easy to find and harvest, they're found in damp, dark places like most other mushrooms, which means there are often other useful fungi nearby. Collect a lot of Cairn Bolete so it can be used in the Mortar & Pestle to rank up the Alchemy skill at a low cost.

6 Images
6 Images

item.title: Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 - Italian Job Walkthrough
item.description:
The Italian Job is a main story quest in Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2 , tasking players with pulling off a high-stakes heist at the Italian Court in Kuttenberg. Success requires assuming the identity of an Italian Cardinal and working alongside allies to steal a secret hoard of silver, all without drawing the attention of the city’s guards.

Along with the heist, KCD2 raises the stakes by adding a rescue mission to free the captured lords, including Rosa’s father. With so much at risk, the mission can quickly become overwhelming. This walkthrough covers each step of The Italian Job, offering strategies for managing conversations, avoiding combat, and pulling off a clean escape.

How to Complete the Italian Job Quest in KCD2

The Italian Job begins immediately after the quest Oratores, as Henry and his allies prepare to infiltrate the Italian court assembly in Kuttenberg. Players take control of Godwin, the only group member fluent in Latin — though only when he is drunk. Managing Godwin’s intoxication becomes critical to avoid suspicion.

Walk to the Italian Court

The first objective is to meet Jerome Naaz at the Italian Court in Kuttenberg. Along the way, Godwin interacts with locals, including two merchants who flag him down. Players should buy at least one item of food and one piece of art to satisfy them before moving on.

Closer to the court, a guard will greet Godwin. Respond politely to build reputation. Naaz will then escort the group into the court. Choose the following social options for the best results:

  • “Let us not waste time.” (Step inside.)
  • (Evade) when Naaz asks about Henry.

As the group proceeds, Godwin should ask Naaz about the Mint to keep the conversation casual. After a brief stop where Naaz complains about the captured lords, they encounter a real Italian guard, Giuseppe. Since Godwin is beginning to sober up, it's best to remain silent and move forward without raising suspicion.

Attend the Council

Inside the court, Godwin finds himself mediating a feud between two religious groups, awaiting a ruling from the Pope. Players must carefully navigate conversations in Latin to maintain their cover.

When prompted, choose:

  • (Continue informally)
  • "Could I also taste the monastery wine?"
  • (Continue formally)
  • "The Pope has not reached a decision."

At this point, Godwin can freely move around the room. It’s crucial to keep him drunk, but not excessively, to maintain fluency. Use the wine kegs on either side of the room, drinking about two back-to-back to stay sharp.

Janosh soon pulls Godwin aside and advises him to ask Naaz for wine to remove some guards. Before approaching Naaz, drink from the keg to ensure Godwin's drunkenness is at least halfway full. Then request wine when the dialogue option appears.

Next, players should speak with all the council members. Focus conversations on the council's purpose and demands; avoid talking about the city. While speaking with Andrew Polner and

Wencelas Vorsucher, ask about the guards to prompt Godwin to request additional guards from Naaz, clearing the way for Henry’s team downstairs.

Be wary when talking to Albich of Uniczow because he knows the real Cardinal. Evade him when he brings it up, and then ask him about the basic premise of law to move things forward. When speaking to Musa , don't mention anything about the murder at Sigismund's camp .

Don't ask unnecessary questions, or Godwin may sober up.

After speaking to everyone, drink more wine if needed, and then discuss the final speech with Janosh. Godwin will need to show off his Latin prowess one last time, so choose the following options for the best results:

  • "Musa is right (Path towards reconciliation)
  • "You need to understand each other."
  • (Calm Down)

With a tentative agreement reached, the conversation concludes, and Godwin must wait and hope that Henry does his part. Luckily, players get to decide their fate, and the game cuts back to Henry's POV.

Take Out the Guards

Henry's side of the plan requires him to get his hands dirty. He must take down the remaining guards to help his comrades steal the silver, so he should equip his best stealth outfit. Exit the door and climb the ladder to the battlement, then turn left and climb onto the ledge.

A guard stands at the corner of the staircase. Sneak up behind him and knock him out or stealth kill him if Henry has a knife equipped. Another guard patrols nearby. After dealing with both, head downstairs to the courtyard to find a third guard. Once all threats are neutralized, meet Vauquelin Brabant near the west gate. Because Brabant refused to kill his assigned guards, Henry and Hans must cover for him. After meeting by the well, the group moves to the next objective.

Look for Adder

Before they can go much further, the trio realizes they are missing someone. Ask about Adder whenever prompted. Henry can follow Hans to find Adder, but they will hear him, or at least his partner, before they see him. Open the door to the room from which the sounds are coming to trigger the next cutscene.

Adder and the pretty cook are getting busy in the kitchen when they are confronted by her husband, Giuseppe. Upon entering, calm everyone down to avoid violence. Then choose the following social interactions:

  • (Pretend to be Italian)
  • (Use Brabant's Phrases)
  • "Fatta la legge, trovato l'iganno."

Help Zizka and the Rest Into the Court

Talk to Adder, then proceed to the cellar to meet up with Zizka and the others. Follow Hans to the lower area of the cellar and look at the wall across from the entrance. Hit "Explore" to bust them through the wall.

Free the Lords

Once everyone is reunited, players must free the captured lords before running off with the stolen silver , a critical step for those pursuing Rosa's romance subplot. Talk to Rosa and the others in the courtyard and choose the following interactions:

  • "We must free the lords!"
  • "I want to go with them."
  • "Got it!"

Henry, Janosh, and Adder go upstairs to where the lords are being kept. There is one man in the way, but players have several options when it comes to dealing with Csaba. They can try bargaining with him, but it requires passing social checks:

  • "We don't have to fight." (VERY HARD Speech check)
  • "You don't stand a chance against us." (VERY HARD Chivalry check)
  • "Join our side." (VERY HARD Charisma check)

Success convinces Csaba to flee and report false information to Sigismund. Failing the checks forces players to kill him. Either way, pick the lock to free the lords.

Escape to Ruthard Palace

Speak to Zizka at the battlements to plan the escape. Just as victory seems near, Erik and his forces attack. Players must defend the battlements, knock down ladders, and fight their way to the outer Bailey.

Afterward, retreat through the cellar tunnel back toward Ruthard Palace. In the tunnels, talk to Musa and Adder to gather the team and begin the final leg of the escape. Players also have a chance to flirt with Hans during this sequence. Upon reaching Ruthard Palace, players face a final skirmish against Brabant's men. Once the enemies are defeated, the group flees to Suchdol, and the next main quest, Civitas Pragensis, begins.

12 Images
12 Images
